name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Society

transcript.content: Hello, I'm Ricky Gervais. To some society is a cage, trapping and oppressing freethinking individuals. But to others, society offers essential structure and regulation, preventing anarchy in the worst excesses of human behavior. Each society has its own codes of conduct, ways of doing things. But who decides these social norms, and how are they governed? From the formative democracy of ancient Greece, to the communist totalitarianism of Soviet Russia, history has shown us that there are as many forms of society as there are people to populate them. To discuss society and our place within it, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award-winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington. You know the score: Little. Round. Headed. Twat.
Alright?
Intro music

In ancient Greece, every year, 500 people would be selected from that Grecian society and they would have to sit there that year and they would propose laws and everyone else would vote on them. And that was their obligation. They were obliged to be one of that 500-- A bit like jury duty, called up, and then they had to propose their ideas and then the rest of the citizens voted on it. Now, if you're in that position, right, you're called up, what rules and laws are you instigating?
You might go, "Right, I want an egalitarian society. I want freedom for people. I don't want slavery. I don't want any sort of oppression." Would that be high on your list?
You could say, you know, when I worked a Cordon Bleu, there was times when I thought "I'm being treated like a slave here."
You weren't
You weren't though because you were being paid, and you were free, so...
What do you mean? I wasn't free. I was on like from 9 till 6.

You had a choice to leave the job, slaves didn't have a choice to leave. They wouldn't go: "Actually, Mr. Jackson, I'm thinking of leaving your employment. The money's no good and I don't like the... clothes." They didn't have that choice.
I didn't have a choice. The only other choice was Tesco and they'd already turned me down.
No, that's not... No. That wasn't the lack of choice given to most slaves.
The slaves who built the pyramids-- That wasn't an option for them. It wasn't like, they can go: "Well, I can get a better gig on the Sphinx!"
Yeah (laughs)
Well, I'm just saying
No, you're not saying anything, You're saying absolutely drivel again...
Here's a little Greek proverb for you: "A society grows great, when old men plant trees whose shade they know they shall never sit in."
What do you think of that? That's amazing.
Can you say it again?
Say it again.
A society grows great when old men plant trees, whose shade they know they shall never sit in. Do you understand?
Yeah. Just saying... They're planting a seed, they grow a tree. But a trees take ages.
Yeah
It takes a long time. That old fella is not going to get any joy out of that.
Right.
But if he's lucky, fella the next door might have done the same, years ago. So it's all about, sort of, planting the seed, looking after each other.
That's great actually. I don't think it's directly--
It's almost, it's almost the point.
That's good, yeah. I think he means that future generations-- But yeah, if the next door neighbor done that, then that works as well.
You seem to agree that that's a good point. Do you agree that seems a good point to you?
But I'm sort of guessing he enjoyed gardening anyway, part of the enjoyment was in planting that seed...
No. We shouldn't have...
Ah... It's the old metaphor problem again, isn't it?
I know, yeah.
It's not specifically about trees. You know, you plant the tree, as you say, and you may never see the beauty of all the benefit of that tree, but other people will.
But as a metaphor, what he enjoyed is the fact that he's added to society and human life and he's got a legacy and all that, so..

But by the same time-- When I went to Ibiza, right? Now, there they have motorbikes. People flying around on them. People don't wear helmets. You might even get three people on a moped. I saw a farmer with a goat in a basket. They don't care. They're whizzing around at high speeds. A lot of deaths there.
Yeah.
And they'll have a lot of them-- See those areas where someone's come off, been killed, people put flowers there.
Yeah.
And because that happens a lot, it's a lovely green island. Now, here we're saying, wear a helmet
Woah, woah, woah! You're saying that all the deaths make it nice because there's flowers?
Because there's loads of flowers everywhere.
It makes it lovely. So with death comes beauty. So that's another metaphor, you can have that one!
That was one of the most torturous things I've ever-- That was extraordinary! That was extraordinary, Karl.
Right, Karl...
But look at London! Let me finish me point!
Let him finish his point, let him finish! I'm intrigued.

Right. London: counselor with his clipboard "Need a speedbump here, I saw someone doing 35. Put some traffic lights there and a pedestrian crossing! Pelican crossing there as well. And a speed camera."
Right.
Horrible and gray.
Okay.
No flowers.
But you still see flowers left behind where people have died in terrible accidents. You see that all the time.
Not very good ones. It's stuck to a lamp post elastic damn round them.
Ricky laughs
They don't look very nice.
He's noticed the quality of the flowers!
Wow!
Yeah, but the point is this...
Some 15 year old got run down and you're disappointed at the quality of the flowers!
(as Karl) Look at this Suzanne! Fella lost his head here! Geraniums?! Geraniums for fella lost bloody head?! Fuckin' hell..."
Well, that's funny you say that though...
We have to encourage gun crime, so that people get shot in inner cities and then we can put flowers up and beautify the areas, is that what you're saying?

No, but if an area is nicer to look in-- Nicer to be in-- If it's nicer looking... You don't get people speeding around like lunatics. Because they go "I'm not in a rush, I'd quite like to slow down there, look at the flowers."

This is so complicated! So now what you're saying is, because an area is gray and gloomy, people speed around to get out of it. In the course of doing that, they knock people down, but then flowers are put up, which then makes the area beautiful, thus stopping people driving around at speeds, so deaths no longer occur.
Well they keep getting out of their cars to put down flowers...
And they get knocked down!
Yeah, yeah.
By other people on their way to put some flowers down.
Just sometimes people have to die, don't they? There was a fella outside our house, who hit a lamppost. He had a helmet on, but his head came off.
Ricky laughs
You made me laugh at a man's head coming off because the way you said it!
But that's the thing!
He had-- He had-- Oh, god! "There's a man, outside our house"
"He had a helmet on, but his head come off."
(laughs) So you're saying that because in that one instance, the helmet did not save his life...
His head was in great condition. It's just not a house to his body.
Ricky & Steve laugh
And that's what I'm saying to you. Sometimes people have to die. How far do you take all this stuff of... safety gear, and slowing down, and wear bright clothes at night... It's just too much!

Very important point you see? We give people crash helmets. We give them seat belts, we make them wear that, right? Do you think that's right for a start? Do you think someone should be made to wear a crash helmet? They're only hurting themselves!

Crash helmet... I don't think you should get fined for not wearing one, but then if you come off a motorbike and you hurt your head and you didn't have a helmet on, then you can't sort of go "Well, they should have had speed bumps here! I didn't realize we were going too fast!"

Well... Don't forget, we're not just protecting him. He could be a father with two kids. So you're going "Oh, let him-- If he doesn't want to crash helmet, let him. Let him get brain damage." Is that what you're saying?
I'm just saying, we're over the top in this country.

So you're saying-- If you're saying "No, if he doesn't want to crash helmet, let him not wear a crash helmet." He doesn't wear a crush helmet, he comes off his bike, he smacks his heading. He's a vegetable. He's like that (makes div noise) sitting at home. And yet the two little kids come to you. You're in charge, don't forget. We've put you in charge of society here, and they come to you, wwo little kids, they go:
(as little kid) "President Pilkington"
"What?"
"Why did you let my daddy wear-- Why not wear the crush helmet?"
"I didn't. We paid-- We put leaflets through the door, we had adverts on the telly, sunshine. It's your dad's fault."
"But why-- But why wasn't it compulsory? Because he might-- it's--"
"It's not the world we live in, sonny."
"Yeah, it is... now I haven't got a daddy!"
"Has he got a helmet at all? Have you seen a helmet knocking about?"
"He's a vegetable now."
"Yeah"
"He didn't want to wear a crash helmet. But why didn't you make him wear a crash helmet?! It wasn't just him, it was us! (cries) Why did you turn my daddy into a vegetable?"
"Where's your mom?"
"Mum left when... he kept going on about not wearing a crash helmet..."
"Alright then. We'll put you in a home!"
Ricky wheezes with laughter
I just think this is the problem. Everyone's looking for someone to blame!
Yes, but... This is interesting, though, because you were particularly calloused to that little four year old boy. He seemed so sweet and adorable...
Yeah.
But why wasn't he giving his stick to his dad?
His dad's a vegetable!
He's good as dead to him.

His dad went within the law. It was not the law to wear a crash helmet anymore, because you said "Forget it, I don't want an anti-state. I don't want-- If you wear a crash helmet or not. He wasn't a responsible parent! He hadn't thought it through. But this is your job! Some people aren't responsible. Society keeps them on track. You were in charge. You should have made him wear a crash helmet! He had two kids!
We heard from one of the kids. What's the other one's attitude? Is he-- Is he a younger one?
He's a little bit younger.
He's even younger still?
(as young kid) "President Pilkington."
"Aaahhh..."
"My brother's crying now. Because you shouted at him. I wish you'd have made my daddy wear a crash helmet.
"Why didn't you make your daddy wear a crash helmet?"
"Well he didn't listen to me, because I'm not in charge, am I?"
"He didn't listen to me! He seems like a bit of a numbnut, not to be honest..."
"No, he did listen to you! Because you've made a new rule, sayin people don't have to wear crash helmets."
"Right. Right."
"And he listened to you!"
"Did he pop shoes on in the morning when he went out? Or did I need to be here to tell him to do that as well?"
"Well, no, there's certain things..."
"Oh, so he has got some common sense, then! Alright, interesting. So he could bother with his trainers, why couldn't he bother with a helmet?"
"Why are you getting angry at me now, I haven't got a daddy!"
"Jesus!"
Wow. You are cruel to this kid! You are mean spirited to this kid.
All I'm saying is... There should be a leaflet...
I don't even know how he got in Number 10, this little kid...
The thing is...
But he's got in, you should have at least a courtesy to listen to his point.
Forget all-- I'm sick and tired of having adverts on the telly: "Don't smoke! Wear a helmet! Slow down! Watch your kidneys!
Steve laughs
I haven't seen that one!
Look after your liver! No, I don't know why... why can't they just put a leaflet through, saying "Hello everyone, use your common sense!" That's all I'm asking
Because some people don't have common sense! Some people are fucking idiots!
It's not my fault then. Not my fault.
Yeah. That's why there is a government! If we let people-- They'd be fucking idiots! They'd be eating Turkey Twizzlers and fucking watching Big Brother and X-Factor all day...
They are doing.
And let their kids run riot on the streets.
But they are doing! Some families do just eat Turkey Twizzlers. There is little knobheads on bikes playing out until God knows what hour.
Exactly!
So it's happening anyway.

YEAH BUT THAT'S NO ARGUMENT, IS IT, "IT'S HAPPENING ANYWAY"!! That's no argument, Karl! It's what we talked about here... Social responsibility! The reason people get into politics is because they think it's their obligation to change those things. This is your approach: "I wash my hands of the whole affair."
Yeah. I don't know-- The people who don't wear a helmet, sort of-- They're doing themselves in and that's cleared them off, that's one problem sorted.
So you think-- You're being Darwinian, you're thinking survival of the fittest--
Yeah!

...The idiots will soon--- But they don't! Because they're not just the victims. The dead person isn't the victim. It's a, you know... A very good example is, okay, we've talked about before: You know, people who smoke know that it's dangerous. We know now, that smoking gives you cancer. But why is that still legal? And yet people know that, and they still smoke. Fat people know that they're going to get out of breath and clammy... And yet they still eat more, they get depressed, they're eating more. They know they're going to be constipated for a year and a half, but they're still shoving in chocolate cake instead of carrots.
But beacuse... that's what I'm saying!

Why don't we stop them? Why don't we stop fat people eating? If you got a smackhead and you really love him, you intervene. You grab him, you put him in the cupboards, you go "You're not coming out!" He goes mad for about a year, then he thanks you for it.
Yeah.
So block fat people in the cupboard. And just put carrots under the door
You can't get them in!
Steve & Ricky laughs
The thing is, there's got to be some responsibility...
Karl, grab Ricky! There's a cupboard over there...

You've got to take some responsibility, haven't you? Now, if it's your own fat kid, stick him in your cupboard. But what I'm saying is, as a counselor, I'm not spending taxpayers money on cupboards to put the fat kid in.
Ricky slams the desk while laughing
So back at the chosen 500, in ancient Greece, right? You're one of them, what other things--
I like that saying-- The one about "Do to others as you'd like to be treated yourself."
Yeah
That's a good one. Pop that on a leaflet. Pop it through the door.

But you seem to be doing a lot of leafleting. That seems to be-- your entire governance seems to be guided by popping leaflets through doors. And I get a lot of leaflets, so I'm presuming the rest of the country does, and it's not always working. So maybe sometimes you've got to instigate something to be a little bit more strong-minded than fucking leaflets, my friend.
Yeah.
You've got to make a couple of laws, you've got to stand up...
Also, this thing that every individual can go, "How would I want to be treated? Um, well, I'd want someone to throw cake at me."
Yeah.
Because I'm a greedy bastard.
I would want someone to steal my telly.
I'd probably start on the way you look.
Right, go on.
I'd just- I'd just say, "Right, you know, make an effort. Tidy up your house." And I'd have some sort of, um...
"I'm poor"
Doesn't matter, doesn't matter. You can still tidy up, love.
"Can we get better houses then? 'Cause..."
Well look after the one that we've let you. Get rid of that old mattress that's in your garden there.
Ricky laughs
Clean the windows. And then we might give you a nicer one. At the moment, you don't deserve anything nicer. And that's what I'm saying. You've got to be honest with these people. Wake 'em up!
I like that.
Sure, you've got to be honest with them, you've got to wake them up. Through a heavy leafleting campaign.
[Laughing] Yeah, yeah!
But do you see the problem with some of what you're saying, Karl, is that it's very hard to, uh, to enforce that--
Yeah.
--in law because it seems unjust and unfair. You can't really start legislating against people's looks or whether they want--
I don't mean--
I mean, you have to keep your house tidy? I mean, who decides how tidy it has to be? The tidy police? I mean, that's a strange--

Yeah. Well, hold on, though. I, um, I like wearing sort of these, these, um, denims. It expresses who I am. And I like wearing a beard because I just think it's natural. I don't like, really like shaving. And yeah, I like this sort of smell. I like this smell of B.O. That's who I am as a person. So I don't-- how can you impose that on me just to be part of the society? Who are you to infringe my rights as an individual?
What do you want out of life?

Well, no, I think-- I'd just like to say I don't, I don't want to conform. I don't want to just shave and wear a suit. And, you know, I keep myself to myself. And I like to, uh, just grow a beard, uh, and eat porridge with my hands. I'm not hurting anyone, so I don't know why I have to conform to that society.
Well, there's nothing I can do for you. You're... yeah, wasting me time, really.
Although I do feel ill. I need to go to hospital now. Um, so I'm going to go to hospital now. So uh, I'm going to go to hospital now if that's alright? Is there- is there- is there care for me?
Well, what's up with you?
I've got diseases from, like, eating with me hands and there's things growing in me beard.
Right.
Um, so will you just-- will you clean it up for me now?
No, 'cause it's all been brought on yourself.
Well, no, but that's irrelevant. A lot of people bring things on themselves, but you can't just, like, ignore them because it's [mumbling] society...
How do they learn then?
I don't know why I'm being punished for being stupid.
How do they learn then?
Well, I've got--
I don't understand why I've got to worry about you. We've got proper ill people.
Well, there--
You had a kid whinging at me this morning because his dad was a mong.
Ricky laughs.
Obviously, in China you can only have, uh, one child, can't you? Is that something you feel we should bring in here?
Uh, yeah, I think we, we've gotta uh, I don't know about one kid. I'd just sort of concentrate on who can have a kid.
Okay.
'Cause if I was to, y'know-- if someone's got a load of money and they're good at looking after kids, let Madonna have as many as she wants.
So social engineering you want to-
Yeah but then-- But hold on-
What you said, if you're bringing him into a poor family, what's the point? What good is that for anyone? It's not good for the people who've had the kids-
So who's deciding who's allowed to have how many kids? You're deciding?
I was brought into a poor family, wasn't I?
What?
I was brought into a poor family.
No, I'm talking really poor.
So, third world.
No.
What poorer than that? Poorer than no money at all?
No, somewhere in the middle again, you've gone too far the other way.
Okay, so...
Why people always have to go the other way?
...Cornwall.
I just mean like the people who I have told you about on the estate sometimes you had that one who chased cars and stuff. He wasn't happy. They didn't care if he was there or not. What's the point?
So hang on. So let's imagine that Ricky and I, our husband and wife, we've come in, right? What's your questions to us to establish whether we are allowed to have a couple of kids?
(as wife) "Hello"
"Hello. Thanks for coming in."
"Me and my husband... We can't have children..."
"Why not?"
"Because he's got no sperm at all."
"Okay."
"He had one sperm and it was... ridiculous, it was awful. It just came out like a dead anchovy."
"Right..."
"And you're meant to have 300 million tiny ones and he had one big one, it was horrible, I had to pull it out. I was like a leech... And also... I haven't got a vagina."
"Completely smooth down there, like an action man."
"Yeah... but we love children and... we wondered if we could have a child."
"What do you do for a living? What do you do? What's you work?"
"I'm a rapist."
Wheezing laugh from Ricky
"Alright then."
"And I dispose the bodies."
"Alright. Fill out this form."
(laughing) "I should have clarified: A rapist murderer."
"Fill out the form."
"He does it in the wrong order as well, I must say so... number of times I've disposed the body and he said I didn't make that one!"
"I know. We just wondered what else you need to know about us? Because even though I have a..."
"That was our little joke by the way, he doesn't... rape and I don't..."
"Of course not! I work in an office."
"He works in an office... in the town. I'm a housewife."
"She's a housewife."
"I'm making a little nest, when we have... We adopt a little child."
"We don't earn a great deal of money, but we're good parents."
"We're very good parents!"
"What's that based on? How did you come up--"
"Well, we're good people. You know, aside from a few naughty jokes..."
"We're God-fearing people. We believe that God is watching all of us, and we believe in the Old Testament..."
"And sometimes he tells us to kill and rape."
"Yeah, sometimes he does, yeah. Particularly... We've stoned a couple of homosexuals, this week alone."
"We're joking again!"
"We're joking again. We don't believe in God. We're from an atheist and believe that our time on earth is all we have. And then when we die and we become worm's meat."
"Alright. So you've filled out the form--"
"But we've already painted the back bedroom, that's ready for the little child."
"We painted it black. Because... we want our child to be a Satanist. Joking again."
"Little joke from us."
"Joking again. We want him to be an accountant."
"Yeah."
"Gay accountant."
"Someone say the same thing, only joking of course."

"I think there's too much in society where people are pressured to be heterosexual so we're going to try and make ours a homosexual. So we don't care whether we get homosexual or heterosexual, but I tell you, by the time he's 14, he will be as queer as the Ace of Spades."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
What would you do?
Umm, am I far from where I'm getting off?

So once again, you can't just nip out at the next stop so you can wash your hands of the whole affair. No, you're on that bus. You've still got a number of stops. You live further away than Rosa does because you've got a lovely big house where obviously she doesn't have a lovely place, she can't afford it. So you've got to stay on that bus. You've seen this now. You've seen this bus driver demanding that she gets up, gives up that seat. Maybe she's giving up that seat for you. Maybe you've got on that bus as a privileged white man and she refuses to get up on your behalf.
Uhh, I'd probably go, "It's all right, I'm standing, I'm all right."
But why would you say that? Because you're thinking of the modern day Karl. You're not thinking of the man from the 1950s.

Well, the thing is well, we don't have to go back in time, we can go to a country now where you'd see an injustice, where you were outnumbered by the law of the land. What if Suzanne wasn't allowed to sit with you on buses? What if now a law came in that women were second class citizens and she can't come with you? Wouldn't you go, "no, fuck that. She's sitting with me."

I'd say, "we're only going around the block. We've been to the shopping center. We'll be only 15 minutes. Can you take that bag with you because there's no one sat next to you down there? I'm a bit crammed in up here. There's more blokes on the bus. See ya in a minute." It's not a big issue. I've done it on the train. Where I've booked tickets and they've ended up being different tickets and I've gone, "I'll see you in an hour and a half. I've got an ipod."
But that's luck. That's luck. That's circumstance. One is policy. Surely you can see the difference between a principle and a bit of luck.

Uhm, but it's what you get used to, at the end of the day. I mean, I'm not walking past them, slapping them on the back of the head. I'm getting on. And it's just that's where they sit. That's where we sit. Like men and women going into a separate toilet.
Karl, let's put this to... I mean, obviously, this is too much for your head to... You're on a bus, right? And there's a few white people and they're...
I'm the driver?
And they're being racist to a black kid.
Right, I'd go, If I'm driving, I'd go, "Listen Lads, stop that, will ya?"
If you're going to be racist, can you get off at the next stop and do it there?
"We've all had a tough day. It's the end of the day, we just all want to go home. We've all been working. Uhh, he's not in your way. He's sat in his own seat. Sit back. Calm down. Had enough.
But what if they said, no, we usually sit there. We want that seat. Would you think the black kid's a troublemaker? Would you go, "Come on, just move mate it'd be peaceful."
I'd go, "What do you want to do? Do you want to move so this is calmed down?"
No, no, no, no you shouldn't say that. It doesn't matter if he wants to move or not. It's his right not to move.
"Do what you want, then. If you want to stay there and fight your own corner."
No! He wants to stay there, surely you want to be on the side of right?
"I'm just doing my job here. I'm sat driving a bus, I'm driving a bus for 30 quid a week here and I'm getting a load of grief...
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
But now it's just walking over the little medal.
So, Suzanne, we, y'know, we leave it for a bit.
Leave it - what do you say -
About half an hour. Left it for half an hour.
What did Suzanne want to do? She wanted to interfere, did she? What did she want to do? Just sort of like -
She just sort of said 'Leave it, stop messing with it. It's probably a little bit knocked out. A little bit stunned.'
Sure, let's get on with our lives, she said.
So, I put the leaf on it.
You put on too much Fairy Liquid. Why didn't you use a dishwasher?
So, we go off, and half an hour later I get back in, and I said 'I'm gonna go and see the cricket.'
Where'd you go? Where'd you go?
Just for a walk.

But, hold on. Why didn't you put the dishes in the dishwasher and go for a walk? I don't understand. So, now you're - now there's a dishwasher sitting there bone idle. You're washing up when you could be walking - and then you're still walking.
It's a good job I didn't go for a walk, though, wasn't it? Cause how would that have turned out?
That fight?
I don't know.
There just would've been a pool of blood on your back door.
So I've been out, back in. Had a look. Cricket's still there. Noticed one of its legs - gone.
Aw.
Don't know if the wasp did that. Or the tea towel flick.
Or it was already disabled and that's why the wasp thought, 'this is an easy one'. What if the wasp was helping it?
It wasn't, though, honestly.
But what if it was going, 'Because we're such friends and humans don't understand us, and anyone who interferes definitely don't understand us. Right. He's not an entomologist.'
This is when I got the computer out.
Right.
Had a look, and it's a - what's it called?
Brilliant.
I can't remember. What happened is, the wasp apparently does this a lot, and it stings them in the head.
Not this particular - there wasn't a little profile of this particular wasp, on a kind of police website.
Yeah.
It's just an incident that happens a lot between wasps and crickets.
Right.
So it's stung it in the head. And what happens is - it's that whole thing that we've talked about before, where it lays an egg.
Right.
So I was sort of having a look, seeing if I could see any sort of holes in his head. And it just kept sort of moving its one leg, like 'Aw, I can't handle this'.
What do you mean, moving its one leg?
It was sort of just moving its one leg quite slowly, like it's just come out an operation.
But it's only got one leg. It lost one leg you said.
It's lost one.
Yeah. It's moving five legs slowly.
No, it's just this one big one.
He's got one big leg?
One big leg at the back, now. It's usually got two that uses to jump.
Oh, I see. So uh, okay. Right.
So now it's only got one. It's sort of like 'Uh' it looks groggy.
Is it not a grasshopper if it's jump - is it not - what colour was it?
Sort of, uh, beige.
Oh, it's probably a cricket. Yeah.
So, anyway...
Important.
So, you were worried that crickets aren't aware of the dangers of wasps? You did a bit of leafleting amongst the cricket community?

I just had a look online and saw that, oh, it's a popular thing that happens. It's like a bit of a mugging. It said you can leave them for about half an hour, they normally come round and they don't know they've had an egg put in their head.
There's no way it said, 'leave them for half an hour and they come round and don't know they've had an egg put in their head'. There's no way it said that.
It said they're normally stunned for about half hour.
Have you had an egg put in your head?
Fucking ostrich egg by the look of it.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
No you didn't.
I did, honestly. Honest to God on me mam's life. I said: 'Why, was it shut?' She said-
Hold on, why did you butt in?
Why did you get involved?
She wasn't even talking to you.
Honestly, I know, it's really, really weird. It's really weird.
But did you have to shout across the dentist's waiting room? Or were you stood next to her?

No no it's was just- it's a small waiting room you see. You got the stairs, you go in, you got about four chairs and then this old desk, and I get on with the woman behind the counter and I always sit close to it and it was just me there and I was talking to her about going to Corfu or something, she comes in sweating like some bison up the stairs.
Ricky Laughs

-and she's there. And because she was showing off, I was like, well, you should have done it a long time ago. I think she annoyed me that she wanted some sort of pat on her- on her big hefty fat back that she hadn't bothered having a doughnut that day. Now, maybe it's the inner me that just came out, because I remember saying it and actually getting home and saying to Suzanne, 'ohh I said this, and I didn't even think- I don't know where it came from.'

I know what you mean though. Sometimes- Sometimes you want to go round with people and they're going [whining sounds]  you want to put them down. You wanna go 'I'm stopping helping you, because you're going to go straight back to that and do this, that. I know you've had a lot- just inject them in the head. Absolutely pointless. Get rid of it. Yeah, I know what you mean. But talking about social etiquette, I was uh flying to Edinburgh and I was with Matt, my assistant, and um there was a bloke on a mobile phone across the way. He was going, 'Yeah, I'm just going to get on a plane now.' And he kept talking that loudly to people, right. And I was fuming. Then he stopped and made another call and I was giving him dirty looks and Matt was going 'no sit down, sit down.' And then he was going, 'Hiya, in the airport!' And I shouted, 'he's in the airport!' He didn't notice. I was shouting over, I was fuming and fuming. And Matt was just getting so embarrassed.
But they don't see it, though.

And people were looking at me like I was the mental case, but it was so fucking loud. And I moved through to another place, but I wanted to get someone. I wanted it to be policed. I wanted to go, Right, there's a cunt over there, swigging beer, thinks he's a fucking Gordon Gecko player and he's not. He's some cunt who's got his first mobile phone. Right? You know what I mean? That is infringing. That is like- That's like passive smoking to me.
Yeah.
It annoys me when you hear these awful middle class parents talking to their kid loud enough to let everyone know what their kid knows. Do you know what I mean?
Yeah.

They bring up conversations because they're showing off about the kid: 'Um, Toby, what's that you were saying earlier about you preferred Beethoven to-?' Right, okay, if that kid talks about Beethoven and Chopin, right... Do you know what I mean, though? It's like people showing off thinking that the world is interested in everything they fucking say. Th-that thing about everyone's got access, which is fine, but it's those fat fucking morons on Docusopes that go, 'I speak as I fucking think,' you useless fucking blob of shit.
Yes. Have an education, research, think, discuss, then offer your opinion.
And stop-
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: President Pilkington's policy on crash helmets
Steve & Ricky try to adopt a child.
